messageBody:
Hi folks,

I am new to JUnit. I have been searching the archives and looking for
information pertaining to my current needs. Having found no answers quit
like what I am looking for I would like to ask for some help in the area of
customizing the junit.swingui.TestRunner.

I was asked to come up with a way for our QA testers to test network Java
applications that have no user interface. The end tester should not be
required to know anything about Java. The network folks will guarantee that
each tester will have a JVM installed on the there machine.

I created 5 classes in the junit.http package called:
HttpTestCase extends TestCase
ServerObject
ObjectHandler
SerializableObject
RemoteTestRunner

I am using HttpTestCase to create myTest were I use a method called
invokeRemoteMethod(
String fullyQualifiedName,
String methodName,
Object[] args,
Class[] argtypes
);

the method uses a ServerObject to store the data about the class that needs
to have it's method invoked, then uses SerializableObject to serialize the
ServerObject and post it to the RemoteTestRunner servlet. On the server the
ServerObject is desterilized and the class is instantiated then with a bit
of reflection the method is invoked. The servlet returns the data to the
client as an object or wrapper object if the return type is a primitive.
All of the is wrapped up in a executable jar file so that the tester only
needs to double click the jar file and then up comes
junit.swingui.TestRunner to display the results of the test.

What I am interested in doing is adding an assertSuccess method to the
junit.framework and extend the junit.runner.TestRunListener with a public
static final int STATUS_SUCCESS = 3 so that I can create a testSuccess
method like the testFailed method found in junit.swingui.TestRunner. I have
traced most of it from the interface on. What I am having trouble with is
how to get message data to print out to the DefaultListModel. I want to say
that there should be a listener for exceptions that is handling the output
to the list box but I can not seem to find my way into it.

If anyone has a previous post or other related reading material they would
care to share, it would be well received.

Thanks for listening to me carry on.

Bryan LaPlante
Network Web Applications
